medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient noted decreased central vision in his left eye the morning before admission. He went to an ophthalmologist the same evening, reporting that peripheral vision in the left eye and vision in the right eye were normal. He did not experience headache, eye or neck pain, flashes of light, or other visual symptoms. The visual acuity in the left eye was noted as 20/400, and he arrived at the emergency department approximately 31 hours after the onset of symptoms.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient had a diagnosis of stage IIB Hodgkin’s lymphoma 10 months prior to admission, presenting with cervical and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, drenching night sweats, and pruritus. Treatment included chemotherapy, which was completed 4 months before admission, followed by radiation therapy completed 1 month prior. He also has a history of Guillain–Barré syndrome diagnosed 10 years earlier, chronic back pain, compression fractures, and cervical degenerative disk disease.
medical_history.family_history: Father had cardiovascular disease, diabetes mellitus, and stroke; mother had arthritis; siblings were healthy.
medical_history.social_history: The patient lived in New England, was married, monogamous with his wife, worked in an office, drank alcohol occasionally, had stopped smoking years earlier, and did not use illicit drugs.
